ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Glenn, All, No, there is not an agreement, not at all. But IMO this interesting thread is are moving in the direction of one. It looks to me that it might

Hi Glenn, All,
No, there is not an agreement, not at all. But IMO this inte=
resting thread
is are moving in the direction of one.
It looks to me that i=
t might be something like

   - RESTful are the services, in the server,
  =
 - that RESTfulness is not affected by the lack of it in the client, and
  =
 - calling a client *RESTful *actually means that it leverages to a great
 =
  extent the advantages of the server's RESTfulness.

--
Juan

On Sun, Mar =
11, 2012 at 15:21, Glenn Block <glenn.block@...> wrote:

> "IMO this =
thread is so lengthy because it started with a "RESTful system"
> idea whic=
h IMO is a wild horse"
>
> Is it? I don't think there is general agreement =
on that statement as Jan
> and others have pointed out.
>
>
> Sent from my =
Windows Phone
> ------------------------------
> From: Juan Lanus
> Sent: 3=
/11/2012 6:26 AM
> To: William Martinez Pomares
> Cc: rest-discuss@yahoogro=
ups.com
> Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the=

> RESTfulness of an application?
>
>
>
> > "A client not obeying the rules=
 does not necessarily remove all benefits
> of
> > REST for the server, tho=
ugh it can if it is the ONLY client."
>
> I don't get this. For example, if=
 I had a fully RESTful server publishing
> a public service consumed by one=
 and only one fully REST-compliant client,
> and somebody created another c=
lient which is not REST-compliant, then what?
>  Would the service be depri=
ved of it's badge?
> Of course it won't!
>
> IMO this thread is so lengthy =
because it started with a "RESTful system"
> idea which IMO is a wild horse=
, the RESTful certificate is only for
> services (the server) and clients c=
an leverage RESTfulness or not, at will,
> without affecting the service's =
quality.
>
> The client can't be RESTful, as it does not communicate with i=
ts (human
> client) user through HTTP.
> --
> JL
>
>  
>

--e89a8ff25198d149d904bafc599d
